text: Lords of the Fallen is the dark fantasy
action RPG that interweavves the realms
of the living and the dead as players
embark upon a perilous adventure to
destroy a demon god. Since its launch in
October 2023, the game has received over
50 post-launch updates, many shaped by
community feedback. With over four and a
half million players across the globe,
that dialogue has been instrumental in
helping forge the game into what it is
today. And now, we're proud to present
version 2.0, the definitive edition of
Lords of the
[Applause]
[Music]
Fallen. Lords of the Fallen launched
with a seamless co-op mode. Unlike many
Souls likes, players could journey
together for as long as they chose. With
version 2.0, You know, we've taken
things a significant step further. From
today onwards, Lords of the Fallen now
features full shared progression
crossplay
co-op. So, how does it work? When two
players join an online session, provided
they're on the same new game playthrough
and have defeated a similar number of
the 12 main bosses within a margin of
one, both players will now retain all
mainline progress. Bosses will remain
defeated and beacons will stay lit or
otherwise. Additionally, in all online
sessions, both players will now receive
all loot, 100% of vigor, and also have
the ability to revive each other,
whether host or guest. Version 2.0 also
introduces the Lord of the Fallen free
friends pass. As of today, anyone who
doesn't currently own the game can now
create a character and explore the
entire tutorial area. Once completed,
players can then join any friend who
owns the base game in online co-op,
ready to continue the journey through
Mornstead side by side. But the question
remains, who do you trust to watch your
back?
Many praised the combat system in Lords
of the Fallen, citing elements including
the focus on dual weapon wielding, the
ability to switch between one-handed and
two-handed attacks midflow, and being
able to equip up to five different
spells at any one time. However, some
players voiced how movement could feel
floaty with attacks sometimes lacking
sufficient weight or responsiveness.
Building on the initial improvements
introduced in version 1.7, which
included a refined roll distance and
tighter animation cancellation, version
2.0 presents a fully revamped character
control and combat system in response to
fan feedback and extensive play testing.
Starting with movement, walk and run
animations are now much tighter. Thanks
to improved physics, your character now
stops almost instantly, offering more
precise control in and out of combat.
Turning your character is also much
faster with a far greater degree of
mobility, while a new dedicated jump
button means you can leap at any time,
adding precision to
platforming. As for combat, every weapon
class has been refined to feel more
responsive in battle. The distance with
which you move when attacking has been
reduced to feel more natural, while a
tighter roll and quicker dash allows for
more effective evasions. The lock on
system has also been modified to ensure
more intuitive enemy selection while
removing the chance to accidentally lock
onto environmental elements during
combat. Furthermore, the soul attack is
now much faster for more effective use
mid
[Music]
combat. While combat fidelity is
integral to any Soulslike, equally
important is how satisfying that combat
feels. And that's where audio comes in.
As well as both block and parry, every
single weapon has received a full sound
overhaul, resulting in a more intense
and gratifying experience. With every
swing, clash, and thud. Alongside this,
the sound effects when striking an enemy
have also been intensified to ensure you
really feel your weapon slice through
every single layer from armor through to
flesh and finally
bone. Another highly popular community
request has been the ability to create
more attractive and generally realistic
looking characters. Both the male and
female options have been visually
enhanced, while we've also increased the
femininity of the female body type with
more attractive face options and a more
conventionally feminine body
shape. The game's UI has also received a
full visual upgrade. It's now cleaner,
more modern, and easier to navigate.
Players can completely disable the HUD
for a more immersive experience or use
the dynamic HUD setting where it fades
in and out based on
gameplay. These UI improvements arrive
handinhand with a fully revised
tutorial. Player prompts have been
streamlined for increased clarity, while
the addition of an allnew guide book
means players can revisit previous
prompts at any time throughout their
adventure. And talking of guidance, your
umbrell lamp now has the ability to
highlight the path towards your next
vestage point, aiding lost crusaders
through the winding passages of
Mournstead. Numerous quality of life
improvements also arrive with version
2.0, including an option for automatic
vigor collection and new button prompts
for both grievous strikes and
environmental soul
flaze. Lords of the Fallen version 2.0 O
is the definitive edition of the dark
fantasy action RPG and is available now
for all lamp bearers. In light we walk.
[Music]
